answers.feedback_html: While solving for resultant vector, one should also consider the direction of the initial vectors.
You can calculate the magnitude of the resultant vector by applying the graphical law of vector addition.
You can apply the law of vector addition to solve it, but first think about what the angle between these two vectors will be.
This is the simple addition of scalar quantities. Vector quantities cannot be added like scalar quantities.

stem_html: Vector \overrightarrow{\text{A}}, having magnitude 2.5\,\text{m}, pointing 37^\circ\! south of east and vector \overrightarrow{\text{B}} having magnitude 3.5\,\text{m}, pointing 20^\circ\! north of east are added. What is the magnitude of the resultant vector?

answers.feedback_html: Backward motion is conventionally considered as negative.
Try it by drawing the positive and negative axes and think about the backward direction of motion. A common convention is that backward is negative.
Conventionally, forward motion is usually considered as moving in a positive direction. Movement towards the right is also considered as positive direction.
A common convention is that motion to the left is negative.

stem_html: While there is no single correct choice for the sign of axes, which of the following are conventionally considered positive?

answers.feedback_html: The magnitude and direction can be calculated by applying graphical law of vector addition.
This is the resultant vector obtained by applying the graphical law of vector addition.
One cannot find correct value of resultant vector by applying scalar algebraic operations. Use graphical law of vector addition.
One cannot add two vector quantities like scalar quantities. Use the vector law of addition.

stem_html: Find \overrightarrow{\text{A}} + \overrightarrow{\text{B}} for the following vectors: \overrightarrow{\text{A}} = (122\,\text{cm}, \angle\,145^\circ) \overrightarrow{\text{B}} = (110\,\text{cm}, \angle\,270^\circ)
